document_title: Ventricular septal defect: Causes, symptoms and treatment
subsection_name: thong-lien-that.json_8_How to care for children with ventricular septal defect
subsection_content:
Children diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect need a special diet and care. If well cared for, children will achieve a healthy state to recover quickly as well as prevent dangerous complications caused by the disease. Specifically: (4)
The energy per serving of children with VSD is often higher than that of normal children. Therefore, mothers need to encourage their children to eat enough nutrients to avoid letting them fall into a state of anorexia leading to severe malnutrition. For babies who cannot breastfeed, milk can be given to the baby through a feeding tube.; Children with ventricular septal defect often have difficulty eating, swallowing, and indigestion. Mothers should divide many meals a day (8-12 meals/day instead of 3-5 meals/day as usual); When a child has complications of heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, or severe cardiac hypoxia, the mother needs to limit the child's strenuous activities; Avoid making children stressed, fussy, and tired; Immediately treat symptoms of constipation and fever in children, if any.
